name: Formal Languages and Compilers
tagline: Notes from the course "Formal Languages and Compilers", Polytechnic University of Turin 2012
body:
## Welcome
This is the GitHub Page for the notes collection project related to the course "Formal Languages and Compilers" (2012), prof. [Silvano Rivoira](http://staff.polito.it/silvano.rivoira/), from Polytechnic University of Turin.
The final document, which is built in LaTeX, consists in a PDF file, in order to make the collection readable in almost every device.

Please keep in mind that this is just a homemade collection of personal notes **without any approval from University or prof. Rivoira**.
I'm not responsible for any bad exam grade nor any consequence derived from wrong usage of this document (see the [license](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/terrinoni/FormalLanguagesAndCompilers-Notes/master/LICENSE))

### Dependences
The repository contains the LaTeX source code so you will need a LaTeX compiler.
Under Linux, `texlive` is your choice ([here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/1017170/3493420) a simple guideline), but you can directly use some kind of TeX IDE like [TeXstudio](http://texstudio.sourceforge.net/) or [Texmaker](http://www.xm1math.net/texmaker/).
If you are a Windows user, I strongly recommend [MiKTeX](http://miktex.org/), which has the great feature to auto-retrieve all the missing packages inside you LaTeX document.

The following is the list of used LaTeX packages:
* [toptesi](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/toptesi)
* [float](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/float)
* [Epstopdf](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/epstopdf)
* [booktabs](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/booktabs)
* [rotating](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/rotating)
* [mathrsfs](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/mathrsfs)
* [amsmath](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/amsmath)
* [caption](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/caption)

### Compile
Once you choose the folder (e.g., `~/git_repoes`) and clone the repository (`git clone <git_repo_address>`) you can compile the code, in order to obtain the final PDF.
Assuming that you're under Linux (and `pdflatex`), use the following commands:
```
$ cd ~/git_repo/FormalLanguagesAndCompilers-Notes
$ make
```
Indeed, the repository comes with a `makefile` you can use to facilitate the compile step.
The command `make view` executes [Evince](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Evince); you can edit the `makefile` in order to use the reader you prefer.

If you use Windows, the `compile.bat` file can be used.
